**US Shifts Focus to China's Growing Influence in Latin America and the Caribbean**
The United States has shifted its foreign policy focus to China's growing influence in Latin America and the Caribbean, particularly in Cuba, where there have been reports of Chinese espionage and possible military cooperation. The Trump administration, led by Secretary of State Marco Rubio, has made it clear that it will not allow China's military presence to expand in the region. One of the most concerning issues for Washington is the alleged presence of Chinese spy facilities in Cuban territory, according to analyst Gordon Guthrie Chang. A Wall Street Journal report found that China has been operating signal intercept stations on the island since 2019, which could pose a threat to US national security due to Cuba's proximity to Florida and the concentration of military bases in the southeastern United States. China and Cuba have denied these allegations, calling them 'baseless', but intelligence reports indicate that cooperation between the two countries has strengthened in recent years. The Cuban regime, facing a severe economic crisis and with Russia distracted by the war in Ukraine, has found a key ally in Beijing to sustain itself financially and strategically. Additionally, there have been reports of the two nations discussing the possibility of establishing a joint military training facility, which could involve the presence of Chinese troops just 160 kilometers from the US. In response to these concerns, Secretary of State Rubio initiated his first tour of Central America and the Caribbean, reflecting a clear shift in US foreign policy priorities. During his visit to Panama, Rubio expressed his concern over China's growing influence in the region, urging the Panamanian government to reconsider its relationship with Beijing. As a result, the Panamanian president, José Raúl Mulino, announced that his country would not renew the Belt and Road Initiative agreement with China and could terminate it before its expiration. The US government has made it clear that it will use all diplomatic and economic tools to contain China's expansion in the Western Hemisphere. Although a direct military intervention in Cuba is unlikely, pressure on the Cuban regime is expected to increase in the coming months, according to Chang's analysis. The relationship between China and Cuba, described last year as an 'unbreakable friendship', could be affected if the Trump administration intensifies its efforts to counter China's influence in the region. The relationship between Cuba and China has been the subject of international attention due to reports of Chinese spy facilities in the island and growing military cooperation between the two countries. In December 2024, a US report detailed the existence of Chinese intelligence facilities in Cuba, located in Bejucal, Wajay, Calabazar, and El Salao. These facilities would be equipped with advanced signal intelligence (SIGINT) equipment, raising concerns about regional security. The Cuban government has repeatedly denied these accusations. In July 2024, the regime denied the presence of Chinese spy facilities in its territory, calling the reports 'baseless'. Despite these denials, satellite images published in July 2024 showed an expansion of facilities linked to China in Cuba, including a new construction 70 miles from the US naval base in Guantanamo. Military cooperation between Cuba and China has also been evident. In December 2024, Raúl Castro and Miguel Díaz-Canel received a Chinese military delegation led by General He Weidong, vice-president of the Central Military Commission of China. During the meeting, both parties expressed their desire to strengthen bilateral military relations. These developments have generated concern in Washington. The US government has expressed its concern over the expansion of Chinese military presence in Cuba and has warned that it is closely monitoring these activities. Despite official denials, the evidence suggests a growing collaboration between Cuba and China in areas of intelligence and defense, which could have significant implications for security in the Western Hemisphere.

**China's Growing Presence in Cuba Raises Alarms in the US**
China's growing presence in Cuba has raised alarms in the US, with reports indicating the existence of listening stations on the island. According to a June 2023 report by The Wall Street Journal, both countries had agreed to establish a new SIGINT site to collect signal information. While the Biden administration initially dismissed the report as 'inaccurate', they later 'declassified intelligence that showed Chinese-operated signal collection facilities had been operating in Cuba since at least 2019', reported the medium. The CSIS notes that this activity may have begun over a decade ago: 'Rumors about Chinese intelligence presence in the island seem to have started with the visit of Chi', referring to the 1999 visit of Chinese general Chi Haotian to Cuba. R. Evan Ellis, a researcher at the US Army War College, told Gatestone Institute that 'the Chinese may have been involved in this activity since 1993'. Cuba's location, just 160 kilometers south of Florida, makes it a strategic location for monitoring US military communications and activities, highlighted by the CSIS. According to the report, 'the southeastern coast of the US is filled with military bases, command headquarters, space launch sites, and test sites'. In addition to the Soviet-era listening stations in Bejucal (Lourdes and Calabazar), new facilities such as Wajay and El Salao are being built, consolidating China's influence in the region. Beijing denied the Wall Street Journal's claims, calling them 'totally false and unfounded', but other elements of the article suggest that these actions are part of the PLA's Project 141 to expand its global presence. According to the US medium, both countries are negotiating 'to establish a new joint military training facility', which could lead to the deployment of Chinese troops on the island, just miles from US territory. Despite China's denials, underlying tensions reflect a possible balance between interests. While Cuba is facing its worst economic crisis since the Soviet collapse, 'the Cuban regime needs Chinese money, and could grant greater access to its territory', argues the CSIS study. However, from Beijing's side, deep economic slowdowns and growing global ambitions may limit its ability to support Havana. The US response has not been passive. Secretary of State Marco Rubio appears to be leading an effort to curb China's expansion in the Caribbean. According to the Wall Street Journal, 'the Biden administration pressed both Havana and Beijing to back down' in negotiations over military sites on the island. In a subsequent interview, a White House official indicated that the US 'will continue to work to interrupt China's presence in Cuba'. In fact, Rubio focused his first official trip as Secretary of State on the Caribbean and Central America region, indicating that this area will be a priority in the Trump administration. In Panama, for example, Rubio questioned the status quo of relations between that country and China, achieving that the Panamanian president José Raúl Mulino announced that he will not renew the memorandum of the Belt and Road Initiative, a key agreement in China's influence over Latin America. 'This status quo is unacceptable', said the spokesperson Tammy Bruce, who added: 'Any delay in immediate changes would require the US to take necessary actions under the Treaty'. The Trump and Rubio strategy, while avoiding military intervention in Cuba, aims to reinforce economic and political pressure. According to The Wall Street Journal, 'China would not be allowed to take control of a country so close to the US'. Meanwhile, the CSIS poses a key question about this Cuban-Chinese alliance: 'Could their cooperation in SIGINT become a platform for a more open military association with Havana?' With a combination of Chinese global ambitions, Cuban financial needs, and an energetic US political response, the balance of power in the Caribbean faces a critical moment. While no additional developments have been confirmed about the alleged listening post, the geopolitical drama between these three nations continues to unfold.
